EDITORIAL.
CO-EDUCATION.
*

HREE very disgusted "grads" sprawled about the seminary table, on
which lay, unfolded, a copy of the morning's paper. It lacked half
an hour before lecture time, and neither the head of the department
nor his stenographer had arrived, (which facts accounted for the
4.%
*•
half chewed cigar in Henkel's mouth.)
"Shade of Ricardo," muttered Spalmer, taking his feet from
the table, and glancing again at the article they had been discussing,
"Women in this department, Gadzooks!
NoiV4 . .
V
4.0
"You will make a pretty picture, Henk, "he added, replacing
his feet, 'rubbing elbows and discussing Malthus with a co-ed."
"Or reading a paper on the division of occupation in the corset industry before a bunch
of psyche knots," added Moore.
"Go to the devil!" growled Henkel. "It's bad enough to have one's breakfast spoiled
about this new co-educational rot, without being inflicted with your elaborations
reading
by
upon it."
"It might not be so bad, after all," sighed Moore. "This woman who starts in today
comes from Smith College, the paper says, and according to Dr. Hardwood there are some
good lookers up there."
"Like ice!" snapped Henkel. "If he ever saw any good looking college women, he
took good pains to marry one out of college. I am willing to wager my degree, that this one
who comes today is as tall and as shapely as a tree-box; wears No. 9 shoes; and looks like
Moore. I never saw a college woman in my life, who didn't wear glasses the size of biscuits,
and walk like a policeman. She will probably talk to us about Kuno Fisher and woman's
rights on the plains of Elah."
"She is not likely to worry you with her conversation," mildly suggested Moore.
"I shall not give her a chance," replied Henkel with a sniff of superiority, "She will
find me dignified but exclusive; which being the case, and since all women must talk, she may
give a portion of time to even such an ossified type of imbecility as yourself—Well I'll be—!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

In the doorway stood a dainty vision of feminine loveliness, arrayed in a tight-fitting
walking suit, an irrepressible gleam of laughter shining from her eyes as she surveyed the
open-mouthered trio.
"May I come in?" she asked looking from one to the other of the men.
"Henkel was the first of the three to recover. Thrusting the cigar into his pocket, he
stumbled to his feet. "Certainly, delighted, have a chair," he blurted out,—and then in a
hoarse whisper to the still dazed Spalmer: "Take your feet off the table, you ass."
"I came in to see Dr. Hardwood. Is be here?"
"He will be here shortly," Moore hastened to say, elbowing Henkel to the background,
"Take off your things,—that is—make yourself at home. The other men will be in soon.
Better sit down; take my chair; nice deep draw there to keep your notes in."
She looked at him, puzzled.
"The Old Man, that is Dr. Hardwood, lectures today," put in Spalmer, "You started
in just at the right time. He's going to talk on the Theory of Crises as applied to the manufacture of bath towels—"
."Are they playing socker at Smith this year?" interrupted Henkel, casting a side-long
glare at Spalmer.
She could scarcely conceal her amusement, but answered gravely: "I was not aware
that they were playing that game up there."
"Why—er—yes, of course they do not. How stupid of me. —This is a great department here. You won't find it so hard at first.— What is your minor course going to be?"
"Why, I don't understand," she said, "You see, I just stopped in a moment to ask
Dr. Hardwood—"
"I see. You have hardly had chance to arrange all those details yet," said Moore, "I
suppose you have used Marshall?"
She was clearly bewildered now. "No—you see—I am not—"
"Well for preliminary work there are other authorities almost as good" said Spaliner,
seeking to come to her rescue, "Some prefer, for example,—"
"But—" began the woman,—
Just then there was a noise at the door, and Dr. Hardwood entered the room. His face
lighted up at seeing the woman, "Well, well," he exclaimed, "You here! Allow me, gentlemen, my wife!"
THE CO-ED.
"The Co-ed she leads a jolly life, jolly life!"—Old Song.

Rejoice! rejoice! ye graduates all,
For the ladies will soon be here;
Some thin and some fat; some short and some tall;
Some pretty (?) some homely,(we fear.)
Rejoice! rejoice? ye undergrads, do!
No co-ed at all need we fear—
Me for the girl with eyes of blue
(And I bet there won't be any here!)
Me for the maid who hardly can tell
Latin from Sanskit or Greek,
But whose language is one that we know full well,
The one we all know how to speak.
Me for the girl whose knowledge of math.
Consists in keeping a score
Of the lovers she's going to have, or she hath,
Here's to HER! May she have many more!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

4

REVAMPS OF THE OBVIOUS.
A Wise man sat by his mill and watched
the circuits which his patient Ass made in
grinding the daily grist. The Professional
Wiseman from time to time trimmed his Lamp
o' Knowledge.
4 4Ah-ha," said he, "Some day I shall be instrumental in setting the World On Fire!
Were I not occupied in keeping this Silly Ass
at work I should do much."
Thereupon the Ass broke loose from the
Yoke and kicked over both the man of Learning and his Lamp.
THE OBVIOUS.

Even a Silly Ass may accidently accomplish more than does the Child of Wisdom by
design.
There was once a smiling Butterfly who
flitted casually from flowers to blossom all
during the golden Summer days making love
to all the Pretty Buds.
One day the Industrious Ant met him
along the road side. "Why are you not
working?" asked the Ant. "When Winter
comes—I who am prudent will have plenty to
eat and a place to sleep."
"I am afraid I will ruin my mind" said
the smiling Butterfly as he lit a cigarette.
There upon the Scullery Maid trod on the
Ant and swept off the Pavement demolishing
his house, chattels and kinsmen. The Silly
Butterfly flew away and being slightly intoxicated late at night, flew into the Conservatory where he staid all Winter the pet of
the household and when he died of old age
among the Orchids, he was put in a glass
case with a golden label in Latin and his
mummy presented to a museum.
THE OBVIOUS.

Wear your good clothes and you may get a
job.
A Cock Robin saw a poor English Sparrow
in a trap. "Ah! one of Hoi Polloi," said he
walking off.
The Vagrant Italian who had set the trap
trimmed, bleached and dyed the Sparrow so
that even in the best Society she was to all
intents and purposes a Yellow Canary and as
such she was sold. As she sat in her Gilded
Cage on a window ledge in Mt. Vernon Place,

the Robin full of envy came to woo her.
"Ah! one of the Yellow Rich," said he about
to compliment her abjectly but just then the
Favorite Angora Cat made her breakfast off
of him.
THE OBVIOUS.

It is better to be in Society even as a pretender, than to be exposed to the Perils of the
Street.

A STUDY IN CIGARETTES.
Young du Bois had not that passion for
eating up work which is thought so desirable
by certain persons. And those who saw his
cheerful face and careless air, which no amount
of trouble displaced, were filled with envy.
A certain fatal cleverness was at his command
and coupled with it a large fund of general
information which usually got him through
troublesome examinations. And yet a certain
sadness filled him this morning as he walked
to the club. Some one was playing Grieg's
"Spring Song" and it awakened memories of
those days when filled with deep resolutions
he had been sent to college. It may have
been remorse from one too many highballs—
but duBois was not given to feeling badly the
morning after. The music sweetly insinuated
him with yearning for home and a riddance
of a less complex life. He lit a cigarette.
CIGARETTE NUMBER ONE.

A collie dog laid at his feet in a drawing
room. The sunlight poured in through open
windows. Family portraits in all stages of
age and size covered the walls. The man
with the smiling face and well-groomed air
was a grandfather. He had fought three
duels and eloped with a charming lady, and
ended up his career by a fall from a horse.
The duelling pistols were above the fire place.
There was another portrait, that of a fine
lady with a proud and haughty face, and yet
a certain soft and kindly hospitality gleamed
from her cleverly painted eyes. They were
green.
CIGARETTE NUMBER TWO.

Pleasant airs blew over blue hills. Large
old houses spread themselves along the ridges.
The horse under him galloped easily. They

THE NEWS-LETTER.

drew up besides a garden wall. He gazed
into it where sat a girl looking down into the
basin of a fountain filled with gold fish. He
quickly dismounted, tied the horse and
stole into the garden full of old fashioned
flowers. Past the sundial. On the sundial
he knew the inscription, "Time flies, but love
is long." And he stole over and kissed the
girl—the girl had green eyes.
CIGARETTE NUMBER THREE.

It was the Cafe Papillon, There were curtained booths and in the open floor many
little mahogany tables. Cigarettes filled the
air with smoke, and a soubrette standing on a
Many women with
table sang a song.
bleached hair and reddened cheeks swept in
and Out leaving a trail of musk behind. It
was Christmas night and the place was in full
swing. A woman smiled with insinuation.
She had green eyes. He started over to her.
But at this moment a fight started. The mirrors were smashed by flying bottles. The
place was in a tumultous confusion. The
woman beckoned. He went over. "Save
me please," she said quietly. "If I stay here
a minute longer I shall be killed, they are
after me." "Follow me," she said. A man
barred the door. He only stayed for an instant for duBois tackled him around the knees.
They were out in the open. Calling a cab,
they were soon far away. And now said he,
"where.shall I set you down?" "Anywhere"
she said. "Well good night," said he.
At home in his lonely room he said, "I
suppose it was because she had green eyes."
CIGARETTE NUMBER POUR.

His exams were a week off. He studied.
His eyes burned, the fever seemed to bake
him. His room-mate came in and found him
delirious. He was put to bed in what seemed
a furnace. For many days and nights he lay
in pain. Weaker he got and weaker.
"There she is—there she is—I knew
it?" "Well Dick I'm done for. She told
Me she would come. This is the third time."
And then men said he died.
"Why .the devil," said duBois smiling,
"do you play such stuff."
"It is no good for this sort of day. Come
on get your tennis clothes and go out to the
Country Club and play tennis, and have tea,
and then by way of amusing ourselves we can
go to the theatre."

5

AN EGOISTICAL PLAIGERISM.
The Prince, Prince Florizel of Bohemia,
looked over his captors—they were twelve in
number, then in his Usual dignified and condescending manner he pulled out his cigarette
case and offered it to the group.
"Gentlemen, will you try a simple paper
cigarette—I assure you that they are quite
innocuous."
Several of the men awaited themselves of
the opportunity—for Prince Florizel as is well
known is in cigarettes as in other things a
connosieur.
Putting the cigarette between his lips he
gazed at them in quiet amusement and said,
"Gentlemen, while I feel greatly the compliment which you bestow on me by my capture,
I can only assure you that you will spend a
sleepless night and I shall leave you in the
morning. I myself awake at ten in the evening and remain awake until daylight. If you
care to sleep tonight I assure you, you will
find me here tomorrow at your service. Otherwise I have no further pleasure than playing
a rubber or two of whist, if any of your number will give me that pleasure. But," said
he, "where is my friend Col. Geraldine."
Thereupon a sullen ill-mannered red-headed
person spoke up, saying, "If we keep him
from the signing of the treaty tomorrow
night we must hurry. The Prince has some
game in delaying us. Come on."
Then gathering his great coat and his kit
bag together they ushered Prince Florizel to
a four wheeler, three inside—three on the box
and took him to the town house of the Russian
charge d'affairs. They led him to a room where
in he beheld Col. Geraldine eutirely tied up.
The dinner dishes were on the table. The
Prince however very cleverly palmed a dinner
knife as he lit a cigarette let it slip up his
sleeve. The Prince strolled over to Geraldine
and said "I will call for you at noon tomorrow." (Here says my Arabian author, is
shown the charming ease and savoir faire of
the Prince on all occasions.)
The Prince was then tied and taken in the
four wheeler to the town house of the Russian
Ambassador. The doors were locked, the
shutters barricaded and the Prince tied securely
in a chair, but so as to allow the use of his
hands in cards.

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Here they played—the Prince smoking innumerable cigarettes which he always offered
to each of his guardians in turn. The night
wore on; at four the Prince and his partner the
Russian Ambassador were much the winners.
"And now" said they,"you must go to bed."
So saying they tied the Prince head hands and
feet to a couch and leaving one as a watch
they took their station in a bed before the
door.
After being tied for some time in this uncomfortable way the Prince suggested that he
be again tied upright, for as yet the Prince saw
no opportunity of escape. So tied in his chair
he again made the goaler play cards with him
and they smoked more of the inexhaustible
supply of cigarettes.
So the night wore on, the Prince unannoyed and indefatigable but everlooking for
a chance to escape. The Prince now decided
it was about time to go. But he was tied
wrists, arms, body, knees and feet to the
chair.
"Will you have the goodness," said he "to
cover me with a blanket; I am chilled from
my cramped position." It was done.
After ten minutes pause.
"Will you have the goodness," said he "to
cover my knees with my great coat." It was
done.
Time, ever undetainable, went on, breakfast
time drew near. The Russian Ambassador
and the Charge 'd Affairs withdrew to partake
of breakfast.
All the while the guardian played solitaire
by the Prince's side.
"I wish that I were in my quarters at
home" said the Prince.
"Why," said the man.
"Because," said the Prince, "I have some
choice whisky there, and I am very cold."
"As your highness is in no danger of seeing
his quarters till after the treaty is signed, if
he will allow me I will be glad to accomodate
your highness." Thus speaking he walked
across the room.
"No thank you" said the Prince, "I seldom
drink, but when I do I don't care for fusil
oil. I think I will go and get my own."
Thereupon the Prince arose, sprang for the

door, unlocked it. The guardian was there
immediately. They grappled, there was a
short struggle.
"And now" said the Prince "I think I will
see after my own whisky."
So saying he bade the attendant a courteous good-morning and walked to his quarters,
gathered his men and set out for Colonel
Geraldine.
"For," said he "it is only right that I
should thank my host for the service of this
useful table knife."
Here narrates my Arabian Author the
Prince put in his mouth one of his well-known
brand of cigarettes.

MAN AND SUPERWOMAN.
On one of his rambles through the town
my friend Jack Crawford came to a street that
had an indefinable charm. Were the houses
magnificent? They were not. They were
dingy structures leaning some into the street
and some sideways. Here and there was a
shutter creaking in its one good socket and
tarnished brass adorned the long unpainted
doors in the form of knockers and doorknobs.
Peeps at decayed gardens and courtyards he
sometimes caught in which strange cats, none
too sleek, sunned or refurbished their habits.
Jack wore flannels and looked well tubbed
and groomed, even to his straw hat with its
club ribband flashing in the warm airs of the
morning in latter sprit. So he was particularly annoyed when a breeze blew his hat
over a wall into one of the gardens. He entered the garden by means of a gate in the
wall, and was about to go out with his recovered headgear when he saw a sundial in
the middle of the boxed garden plots.
"Staye while ye can
Time stays for no man."
Thus ran thelegend on the sundial.
"Devilish good advice! This spring
weather has gotten into my walking apparatus." So saying he sat down on a stone
bench, for the house seemed deserted and he
had little fear of being caught intruding.
"I wish to heaven I had a mint julep"
said he looking at the mint bed which was
planted round the little fountain."
"You may," said a woman's voice above

THE NEWS-LETTER.

him on a balcony hidden in the vines.
If Jack had not been used to surprises and
mint juleps he would have vanished, but his
love of adventure held him.
"Thank you very much," he said uncovered and bowing to his unseen hostess.
"I'll be down in a minute."
"Two minutes later a little negro boy in
white jacket came out with a small decanter,
ice and all the other ingredients of that delightful drink, the mint julep.
Three minutes later a girl in white summer
things strolled across the garden.
"How do yo do," said she.
"Very nicely, thank you."
"Help me gather the mint," said the good
looking girl.
Thereupon Jack gathered the mint and said
to himself "you are drunk," and then remembered the translation from Hafiz which
he repeated to himself.
"Ah! Hafiz, thou art drunk,
Drunk with the Infinite,drunk with the Divine,
Drunk with music—drunk with love
Ah! Hafiz thou art drunk with wine!"
"I like Hafiz—but not as much as FitzGerald Omar," said the amazing young
lady.
"How did you know what I was thinking
of?"
"Yon may think it strange," said she,
"but I am endowed with what people call
the second sight. Really there is no such
thing, I think. Telepathy, I suppose, it is
useful in diplomacy."
"If I could do it," said Jack, "there would
be no need for conversation."
"0 yes there would, for the same reason
that society finds pleasure in talking. After.
one has been out two seasons one can tell
what people are going to say anyway. And
conversation becomes merely an exercise in
permitations and combinations—or perhaps a
game of checkers."
"Yes there are a certain number of possible obvious moves, the point being to say
all yours first in an attempt to exhaust the
enemy's supply of ammunition and make him
feel uncomfortable, or to get him up in a corner and
"Make him propose," said she. "You
are progressing."

7

He—"Do you like playing with a full
hand."
She—''No, I prefer the long and lingering
game in which there are but two men on one
side and
He—''A Queen in the
She—"Corner? No, because the Queen is
never in the corner, nor does she enjoy a
game unless there is a choice, besides she has
the advantage."
He—"Three alternatives as it were, to capture one, to capture both, or to be captured
by either."
She—"Four! She can move back and forth
in the corner."
He—"And in the case that there was only
one man on the board."
She—"She would tantalize him and pay no
attention to him in the next game."
He—''And what do you think of flirtation."
She—"Precisely what you do—I exercise
my second sight."
He—''And what do I think."
"You in you present state of mind will
think anything I choose to make you think."
"And that is that flirtation is a delightful
game only to be likened to fox hunting and
mint juleps."
"Oh, we forgot them!"
As they drank them she said, "I will
answer your question—that you are going to
ask yourself in ten minutes—I came down
because I saw your hatband—My father wears
one. "Good-bye," said she, stretching out
her hand, "I will see you at luncheon next
Monday. We will continue our game of—
"Checkers."
She was undoubtedly gone.
And Jack Crawford wandered home. He
found a note from his great aunt.
DUAR JACK:
"Come and lunch with me at three next
Monday. Your cousin Hildegarde has come
home from abroad, where she has been with
her father, your Uncle Jim, who is in the
diplomatic corps. She may be a trifle stupid—
for I have never seen her, so please come and
help me out. Bring Dick if you want to.
Your Aunt Caroline.
"But I would rather not," said Jack between cigarette rings. "It is a two to one
shot. But how the devil—what the devil was
she doing down on that street. Well, I will
go and find out!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE PRESIDENT'S RECEPTION.
On Friday, March fifteenth a very pleasant
musical was given to the student body by the
President and Mrs. Remsen in Coy Hall. It
is not often that we, at Hopkins, are favored
with anything but "shop" work, and as one
of the students aptly remarked, it is certainly
most delightful to hear really good music
again. Yet besides the pleasure of an entertainment of this kind there is a real and permanent value in that it gives an opportunity
for social development, and for the improvement and refinement of those qualities which,
though not found on any curriculum are
always expected in a college man. In behalf
of the student body the NEWS-LETTER takes
this opportunity to thank President and Mrs.
Remsen, and would also say that it hopes the
President's reception will become a fixed custom at Hopkins. It is probable that another
will be given soon.

wrote asking for funds to make the purchase.
Mr. Buckley and other generously responded,

the funds were at hand, however, the price

In conjunction with Dr. Wilson, Dr. Robinson will give two new courses next year
open to undergraduates, one on Greek and
Roman antiquities, the other on Greek and
Roman private life. The first will be a three
hour course; the second has not yet been
definitely arranged. At any rate, they will
offer great help to the classical student in
helping him to get into the spirit of the Greek
and Roman writers.

LEVERING HALL.

HOPKINS NIGHT.

INTERCOLLEGIATE CONFERENCE.

The next Hopkins Night will be held on
Tuesday, April 23, at the Academy of Music.
The attraction is the musical comedy "Noah's
Ark." The show is entirely new, and will
have its premiere the night before, with Harry
Bulger, of "Woodland" fame, and Maida
Snyder, at the head of the caste. The comedy
is said to be one of the best of recent years,
and certainly ought to be attractive with
Bulger at its head. This will be an excellent
opportunity for some of the former "supes"
to get a job, and doubtless they would be
well repaid by their experiences behind the
scenes of such a show.
The committee is waking every effort to
have this night a record-breaker, and they
hope that that night will see present a goodly
number of Hopkins men as well as outsiders.
The show is well worth the money, and there
is no reason why we won't have a good crowd,
provided every man conies up at the proper
time.

The conference, held on March 9, was attended by about sixty delegates from twelve
colleges in Maryland and the District of
Columbia. The speakers were Messrs. Fennell P. Turner and J. A. Lovell Murray, Dr.
Griggs of Peking, China, now studying at the
Hopkins Medical School, and Mrs. Hoskins
of Beirut, Syria. Out-of-town students were
entertained by Hopkins men. Supper was
served in Levering Hall.

HOPKINS AT JAMESTOWN.
A space twenty-six by fifteen feet in a
desirable part of the Educational Building has
been set aside for our exhibit at Jamestown.
Our display is limited practically to four lines
representing mainly the scientific activities of
the University.
First. There will be a full set of handsomely-bound scientific journals, theses and
other University publications.
Second. The Biological Department will
be represented by specimens illustrating the
oyster in all its phases of development.
Plenty of information will be on hand in the
various publications previously made on the
subject of the oyster. The cray-fish and

9

THE NEWS-LETTER.

other objects will illustrate the work in
Marine Zoology.
Third. From the Physical Department will
be sent a photographic map of the solar
spectrum, diffraction gratings, and an apparatus showing modifications of the Cavendish experiment.
Fourth. Maps, charts and models will
show work now in progress in Geological
Meteorology.
Publications from the Economic Department
on subjects under recent investigation, specimens of papyrus received from Egypt, and a
tablet, prepared by Dr. Haupt, giving the
Chaldean account of the deluge,will practically
omplete the exhibition.

THE FRESHMAN LACROSSE TEAM.
In spite of all that has been said of the
Freshman lack of spirit, they have gotten
their candidates together and held two regular lineups. Of course, these lineups have
just been to teach them the elementary principles of the game, for only three of the
Freshmen have ever had a stick in their hand
before they came to Hopkins.
The candidates are working hard and show
good spirit, but as the team is mostly new in
every respect, the men will not be assigned to
their positions for some time. The days for
the class games have not yet been decided on.

HOPKINS, 8; MARYLAND AGRICULTURAL
COLLEGE, 7.
On March 30, the baseball team opened its
season by defeating the Maryland Agricultural
College in a very pretty game which took
eleven innings to decide. M. A. C. scored
first, making two runs in the first inning,
but in the fourth Hopkins was two runs
ahead. By the sixth the score was even, and
from that point until the eleventh neither side
could score. In this inning the visitors made
two runs, and it looked as though they might
will out after all. Our chances looked particularly bad when our first two men struck out,
but the third got to first somehow, and then
turned. With a two-bagger from Maynard
we tied the score, and a moment later on a
single from Watkins won tne game.

PENNSYLVANIA, 16; HOPKINS, 1.
On April 1st the team was badly beaten by
the fast nine of the University of Pennsylvania. As a baseball game the exhibition was
exceedingly poor, for it was merely a test of
which set of men could endure the most cold,

TRACK.
The out-door season is on hand for sports
and, already, the members of the Track team
have enjoyed the rush of the wind in their
faces, and have had the pleasure of taking
enjoyable trips on crowded trolley-cars,
through such pleasant quiet scenes as one
find on Pratt street.
The United Railway Company and the
weather man seem bound to keep the track
team from training; the former by not furnishing a more convenient means of transportation
to Patterson Park, and the latter by furnishing a too-abundant supply of snow in the
second week in April.
In spite of these difficulties, however, the
season has fairly commenced, and either because it is the custom or because one naturally feels optimistic after the Easter examinations are over, we find it incumbent to predict
a very successful season.
The first event to come off is the Pennsylvania Relay Races, and needless to say every
one is confident of success, even our opponents. The men are rounding into fine form
(all track men should have good forms, although, alas, many have not) and best of all,
they are not new. Padgett, Stewart, Hunter
and Perce have all had experience on the
team before, and Treading, Graves and the
other candidates for positions all know what
it is to have a track shoe on. The struggle
for places on the team should be hard fought
this year, and that always brings out the best
team possible in the University.
The squad now is quite large. Nearly
every one, whoever pretended to run, is quite
enthusiastic at present, and you can see quite
a few men daily running up and down the

THE NEWS-LETTER.

cage in the abbreviated track suit. The track
picture will be taken soon.
The outlook for the Virginia dual meet
is not so favorable as it was last year. The
loss of Hill, Knight and several other good
men, through graduation or otherwise, makes
it necessary to develop new men to take their
places and at present these new men are not
over-plentiful.
The teams greatest weakness is in the field
events. There is a lack of weight-men and
jumpers, and it is the duty of every man who
ever did anything in these lines to come out
and help beat Virginia.
If Hopkins is to beat Virginia and the
Naval Academy this year, it means hard
work, not hard work by a few, but by a concentrated effort by the whole undergraduate
body. As a united body, we may hope to accomplish much, so get together.

LACROSSE.
As probably every one knows, the lacrosse
season opened on Saturday, April sixth, with
the game between the Alumni and the 'Varsity. The former team was composed of
former players and scrubs from this year's
and, of course, had little or no team work.
Nevertheless, they put up an excellent game
and were the first to score. That first goal
was well earned by the Alumni, and the
'Varsity defense was certainly "up in the air"
when it was made. Coming as it did, after
about three minutes of play, it caused some
of the Alumni to chortle in high glee, and
several of the wiseacres on the sidelines began
to shake their heads and make dire prophecies
as to what would be the outcome of the game,
and even the season. Their doubts and fears
were quickly dispelled later, however, for
when the 'Varsity struck their pace, they did
not let up until the last whistle blew, when
there were 11 goals to the credit of the 1907
team.
The 'Varsity, in spite of their good showing, need not get puffed up. Nearly half of
the opponents were scrubs, some of whom were
playing for the first time in a regular game,
Therefore, because they shot 11 goals is no
sign that they will have an easy time with
Mt. Washington or Swarthmore, later on.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Alumni had no team-work, and were, of
course, in no condition, but the two teams
just mentioned will be in first-class condition
and have excellent team-work by the time
the games come off.
The Alumni defense was stronger than
their attack, and as a result, the 'Varsity attack had to work harder than the 'Varsity
defense. The latter missed the services of
Captain Tough, who thought it wiser to stay
out of the game, on account of a little soreness in his leg. As a result the defense did
not strike the proper gait until the second
half, when the goal was scarcely threatened.
It was pleasing to see Dr. Abercrombie and
some of the other "old men" come out and
show flashes of their old-time form. The appearance of the doctor's red and white cap
called forth remembrances of past days when
the owner of that cap played center, and the
bobbing tassel would be seen in all parts of
the field.
Dill, Fred. Blanck and "Bill" Schmeisser have been practicing with Mt. Washington, and, of course, are more familiar to the
present generation than Abercrombie, Iglehart and Hazlehurst.
The day was cold, and hence, the attendance was not so good as it might have been.
Let us hope the rooters will come out strong
at the next games. They are all in Baltimore,
except the Swarthmore game, and they will
all be worth seeing. They ought to be just
as interesting as the Swarthmore game of last
year, for the teams are very evenly matched.
Here is a chance for some good hard rooting,
Wake up!

CO-EDUCATION.

HREE very disgusted "grads" sprawled about the seminary table, on
which lay, unfolded, a copy of the morning's paper. It lacked half
an hour before lecture time, and neither the head of the department
nor his stenographer had arrived, (which facts accounted for the
4.%

half chewed cigar in Henkel's mouth.)
"Shade of Ricardo," muttered Spalmer, taking his feet from
the table, and glancing again at the article they had been discussing,
"Women in this department, Gadzooks!

"You will make a pretty picture, Henk, "he added, replacing
his feet, 'rubbing elbows and discussing Malthus with a co-ed."
"Or reading a paper on the division of occupation in the corset industry before a bunch
of psyche knots," added Moore.
"Go to the devil!" growled Henkel. "It's bad enough to have one's breakfast spoiled
about this new co-educational rot, without being inflicted with your elaborations

by
upon it."
"It might not be so bad, after all," sighed Moore. "This woman who starts in today
comes from Smith College, the paper says, and according to Dr. Hardwood there are some
good lookers up there."
"Like ice!" snapped Henkel. "If he ever saw any good looking college women, he
took good pains to marry one out of college. I am willing to wager my degree, that this one
who comes today is as tall and as shapely as a tree-box; wears No. 9 shoes; and looks like
Moore. I never saw a college woman in my life, who didn't wear glasses the size of biscuits,
and walk like a policeman. She will probably talk to us about Kuno Fisher and woman's
rights on the plains of Elah."
"She is not likely to worry you with her conversation," mildly suggested Moore.
"I shall not give her a chance," replied Henkel with a sniff of superiority, "She will
find me dignified but exclusive; which being the case, and since all women must talk, she may
give a portion of time to even such an ossified type of imbecility as yourself—Well I'll be—!"

3

In the doorway stood a dainty vision of feminine loveliness, arrayed in a tight-fitting
walking suit, an irrepressible gleam of laughter shining from her eyes as she surveyed the
open-mouthered trio.
"May I come in?" she asked looking from one to the other of the men.
"Henkel was the first of the three to recover. Thrusting the cigar into his pocket, he
stumbled to his feet. "Certainly, delighted, have a chair," he blurted out,—and then in a
hoarse whisper to the still dazed Spalmer: "Take your feet off the table, you ass."
"I came in to see Dr. Hardwood. Is be here?"
"He will be here shortly," Moore hastened to say, elbowing Henkel to the background,
"Take off your things,—that is—make yourself at home. The other men will be in soon.
Better sit down; take my chair; nice deep draw there to keep your notes in."
She looked at him, puzzled.
"The Old Man, that is Dr. Hardwood, lectures today," put in Spalmer, "You started
in just at the right time. He's going to talk on the Theory of Crises as applied to the manufacture of bath towels—"
."Are they playing socker at Smith this year?" interrupted Henkel, casting a side-long
glare at Spalmer.
She could scarcely conceal her amusement, but answered gravely: "I was not aware
that they were playing that game up there."
"Why—er—yes, of course they do not. How stupid of me. —This is a great department here. You won't find it so hard at first.— What is your minor course going to be?"
"Why, I don't understand," she said, "You see, I just stopped in a moment to ask
Dr. Hardwood—"
"I see. You have hardly had chance to arrange all those details yet," said Moore, "I
suppose you have used Marshall?"
She was clearly bewildered now. "No—you see—I am not—"
"Well for preliminary work there are other authorities almost as good" said Spaliner,
seeking to come to her rescue, "Some prefer, for example,—"
"But—" began the woman,—
Just then there was a noise at the door, and Dr. Hardwood entered the room. His face
lighted up at seeing the woman, "Well, well," he exclaimed, "You here! Allow me, gentlemen, my wife!"
THE CO-ED.
"The Co-ed she leads a jolly life, jolly life!"—Old Song.

Rejoice! rejoice! ye graduates all,
For the ladies will soon be here;
Some thin and some fat; some short and some tall;
Some pretty (?) some homely,(we fear.)
Rejoice! rejoice? ye undergrads, do!
No co-ed at all need we fear—
Me for the girl with eyes of blue
(And I bet there won't be any here!)
Me for the maid who hardly can tell
Latin from Sanskit or Greek,
But whose language is one that we know full well,
The one we all know how to speak.
Me for the girl whose knowledge of math.
Consists in keeping a score
Of the lovers she's going to have, or she hath,
Here's to HER! May she have many more!

REVAMPS OF THE OBVIOUS.
A Wise man sat by his mill and watched
the circuits which his patient Ass made in
grinding the daily grist. The Professional
Wiseman from time to time trimmed his Lamp
o' Knowledge.
4 4Ah-ha," said he, "Some day I shall be instrumental in setting the World On Fire!
Were I not occupied in keeping this Silly Ass
at work I should do much."
Thereupon the Ass broke loose from the
Yoke and kicked over both the man of Learning and his Lamp.
THE OBVIOUS.

Even a Silly Ass may accidently accomplish more than does the Child of Wisdom by
design.
There was once a smiling Butterfly who
flitted casually from flowers to blossom all
during the golden Summer days making love
to all the Pretty Buds.
One day the Industrious Ant met him
along the road side. "Why are you not
working?" asked the Ant. "When Winter
comes—I who am prudent will have plenty to
eat and a place to sleep."
"I am afraid I will ruin my mind" said
the smiling Butterfly as he lit a cigarette.
There upon the Scullery Maid trod on the
Ant and swept off the Pavement demolishing
his house, chattels and kinsmen. The Silly
Butterfly flew away and being slightly intoxicated late at night, flew into the Conservatory where he staid all Winter the pet of
the household and when he died of old age
among the Orchids, he was put in a glass
case with a golden label in Latin and his
mummy presented to a museum.
THE OBVIOUS.

Wear your good clothes and you may get a
job.
A Cock Robin saw a poor English Sparrow
in a trap. "Ah! one of Hoi Polloi," said he
walking off.
The Vagrant Italian who had set the trap
trimmed, bleached and dyed the Sparrow so
that even in the best Society she was to all
intents and purposes a Yellow Canary and as
such she was sold. As she sat in her Gilded
Cage on a window ledge in Mt. Vernon Place,

the Robin full of envy came to woo her.
"Ah! one of the Yellow Rich," said he about
to compliment her abjectly but just then the
Favorite Angora Cat made her breakfast off
of him.

It is better to be in Society even as a pretender, than to be exposed to the Perils of the
Street.

A STUDY IN CIGARETTES.
Young du Bois had not that passion for
eating up work which is thought so desirable
by certain persons. And those who saw his
cheerful face and careless air, which no amount
of trouble displaced, were filled with envy.
A certain fatal cleverness was at his command
and coupled with it a large fund of general
information which usually got him through
troublesome examinations. And yet a certain
sadness filled him this morning as he walked
to the club. Some one was playing Grieg's
"Spring Song" and it awakened memories of
those days when filled with deep resolutions
he had been sent to college. It may have
been remorse from one too many highballs—
but duBois was not given to feeling badly the
morning after. The music sweetly insinuated
him with yearning for home and a riddance
of a less complex life. He lit a cigarette.
CIGARETTE NUMBER ONE.

A collie dog laid at his feet in a drawing
room. The sunlight poured in through open
windows. Family portraits in all stages of
age and size covered the walls. The man
with the smiling face and well-groomed air
was a grandfather. He had fought three
duels and eloped with a charming lady, and
ended up his career by a fall from a horse.
The duelling pistols were above the fire place.
There was another portrait, that of a fine
lady with a proud and haughty face, and yet
a certain soft and kindly hospitality gleamed
from her cleverly painted eyes. They were
green.
CIGARETTE NUMBER TWO.

Pleasant airs blew over blue hills. Large
old houses spread themselves along the ridges.
The horse under him galloped easily. They

THE NEWS-LETTER.

drew up besides a garden wall. He gazed
into it where sat a girl looking down into the
basin of a fountain filled with gold fish. He
quickly dismounted, tied the horse and
stole into the garden full of old fashioned
flowers. Past the sundial. On the sundial
he knew the inscription, "Time flies, but love
is long." And he stole over and kissed the
girl—the girl had green eyes.
CIGARETTE NUMBER THREE.

It was the Cafe Papillon, There were curtained booths and in the open floor many
little mahogany tables. Cigarettes filled the
air with smoke, and a soubrette standing on a
Many women with
table sang a song.
bleached hair and reddened cheeks swept in
and Out leaving a trail of musk behind. It
was Christmas night and the place was in full

She had green eyes. He started over to her.
But at this moment a fight started. The mirrors were smashed by flying bottles. The
place was in a tumultous confusion. The
woman beckoned. He went over. "Save
me please," she said quietly. "If I stay here

They were out in the open. Calling a cab,

"where.shall I set you down?" "Anywhere"
she said. "Well good night," said he.
At home in his lonely room he said, "I
suppose it was because she had green eyes."
CIGARETTE NUMBER POUR.

His exams were a week off. He studied.
His eyes burned, the fever seemed to bake
him. His room-mate came in and found him
delirious. He was put to bed in what seemed
a furnace. For many days and nights he lay
in pain. Weaker he got and weaker.
"There she is—there she is—I knew
it?" "Well Dick I'm done for. She told
Me she would come. This is the third time."
And then men said he died.
"Why .the devil," said duBois smiling,
"do you play such stuff."
"It is no good for this sort of day. Come
on get your tennis clothes and go out to the
Country Club and play tennis, and have tea,
and then by way of amusing ourselves we can
go to the theatre."

AN EGOISTICAL PLAIGERISM.
The Prince, Prince Florizel of Bohemia,
looked over his captors—they were twelve in
number, then in his Usual dignified and condescending manner he pulled out his cigarette
case and offered it to the group.
"Gentlemen, will you try a simple paper
cigarette—I assure you that they are quite
innocuous."
Several of the men awaited themselves of
the opportunity—for Prince Florizel as is well
known is in cigarettes as in other things a
connosieur.
Putting the cigarette between his lips he
gazed at them in quiet amusement and said,
"Gentlemen, while I feel greatly the compliment which you bestow on me by my capture,
I can only assure you that you will spend a
sleepless night and I shall leave you in the
morning. I myself awake at ten in the evening and remain awake until daylight. If you
care to sleep tonight I assure you, you will
find me here tomorrow at your service. Otherwise I have no further pleasure than playing
a rubber or two of whist, if any of your number will give me that pleasure. But," said
he, "where is my friend Col. Geraldine."
Thereupon a sullen ill-mannered red-headed
person spoke up, saying, "If we keep him
from the signing of the treaty tomorrow
night we must hurry. The Prince has some
game in delaying us. Come on."
Then gathering his great coat and his kit
bag together they ushered Prince Florizel to
a four wheeler, three inside—three on the box
and took him to the town house of the Russian
charge d'affairs. They led him to a room where
in he beheld Col. Geraldine eutirely tied up.
The dinner dishes were on the table. The
Prince however very cleverly palmed a dinner
knife as he lit a cigarette let it slip up his
sleeve. The Prince strolled over to Geraldine
and said "I will call for you at noon tomorrow." (Here says my Arabian author, is
shown the charming ease and savoir faire of
the Prince on all occasions.)
The Prince was then tied and taken in the
four wheeler to the town house of the Russian
Ambassador. The doors were locked, the
shutters barricaded and the Prince tied securely
in a chair, but so as to allow the use of his
hands in cards.

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Here they played—the Prince smoking innumerable cigarettes which he always offered
to each of his guardians in turn. The night
wore on; at four the Prince and his partner the
Russian Ambassador were much the winners.
"And now" said they,"you must go to bed."
So saying they tied the Prince head hands and
feet to a couch and leaving one as a watch
they took their station in a bed before the
door.
After being tied for some time in this uncomfortable way the Prince suggested that he
be again tied upright, for as yet the Prince saw
no opportunity of escape. So tied in his chair
he again made the goaler play cards with him
and they smoked more of the inexhaustible
supply of cigarettes.
So the night wore on, the Prince unannoyed and indefatigable but everlooking for
a chance to escape. The Prince now decided
it was about time to go. But he was tied
wrists, arms, body, knees and feet to the
chair.
"Will you have the goodness," said he "to
cover me with a blanket; I am chilled from
my cramped position." It was done.
After ten minutes pause.
"Will you have the goodness," said he "to
cover my knees with my great coat." It was
done.
Time, ever undetainable, went on, breakfast
time drew near. The Russian Ambassador
and the Charge 'd Affairs withdrew to partake
of breakfast.
All the while the guardian played solitaire
by the Prince's side.
"I wish that I were in my quarters at
home" said the Prince.
"Why," said the man.
"Because," said the Prince, "I have some
choice whisky there, and I am very cold."
"As your highness is in no danger of seeing
his quarters till after the treaty is signed, if
he will allow me I will be glad to accomodate
your highness." Thus speaking he walked
across the room.
"No thank you" said the Prince, "I seldom
drink, but when I do I don't care for fusil
oil. I think I will go and get my own."
Thereupon the Prince arose, sprang for the

door, unlocked it. The guardian was there
immediately. They grappled, there was a
short struggle.
"And now" said the Prince "I think I will
see after my own whisky."
So saying he bade the attendant a courteous good-morning and walked to his quarters,
gathered his men and set out for Colonel
Geraldine.
"For," said he "it is only right that I
should thank my host for the service of this
useful table knife."
Here narrates my Arabian Author the
Prince put in his mouth one of his well-known
brand of cigarettes.

MAN AND SUPERWOMAN.
On one of his rambles through the town
my friend Jack Crawford came to a street that
had an indefinable charm. Were the houses
magnificent? They were not. They were
dingy structures leaning some into the street
and some sideways. Here and there was a
shutter creaking in its one good socket and
tarnished brass adorned the long unpainted
doors in the form of knockers and doorknobs.
Peeps at decayed gardens and courtyards he
sometimes caught in which strange cats, none
too sleek, sunned or refurbished their habits.
Jack wore flannels and looked well tubbed
and groomed, even to his straw hat with its
club ribband flashing in the warm airs of the
morning in latter sprit. So he was particularly annoyed when a breeze blew his hat
over a wall into one of the gardens. He entered the garden by means of a gate in the
wall, and was about to go out with his recovered headgear when he saw a sundial in
the middle of the boxed garden plots.
"Staye while ye can
Time stays for no man."
Thus ran thelegend on the sundial.
"Devilish good advice! This spring
weather has gotten into my walking apparatus." So saying he sat down on a stone
bench, for the house seemed deserted and he
had little fear of being caught intruding.
"I wish to heaven I had a mint julep"
said he looking at the mint bed which was
planted round the little fountain."
"You may," said a woman's voice above

THE NEWS-LETTER.

him on a balcony hidden in the vines.
If Jack had not been used to surprises and
mint juleps he would have vanished, but his
love of adventure held him.
"Thank you very much," he said uncovered and bowing to his unseen hostess.
"I'll be down in a minute."
"Two minutes later a little negro boy in
white jacket came out with a small decanter,
ice and all the other ingredients of that delightful drink, the mint julep.
Three minutes later a girl in white summer
things strolled across the garden.
"How do yo do," said she.
"Very nicely, thank you."
"Help me gather the mint," said the good
looking girl.
Thereupon Jack gathered the mint and said
to himself "you are drunk," and then remembered the translation from Hafiz which
he repeated to himself.
"Ah! Hafiz, thou art drunk,
Drunk with the Infinite,drunk with the Divine,
Drunk with music—drunk with love
Ah! Hafiz thou art drunk with wine!"
"I like Hafiz—but not as much as FitzGerald Omar," said the amazing young
lady.
"How did you know what I was thinking
of?"
"Yon may think it strange," said she,
"but I am endowed with what people call
the second sight. Really there is no such
thing, I think. Telepathy, I suppose, it is
useful in diplomacy."
"If I could do it," said Jack, "there would
be no need for conversation."
"0 yes there would, for the same reason
that society finds pleasure in talking. After.
one has been out two seasons one can tell
what people are going to say anyway. And
conversation becomes merely an exercise in
permitations and combinations—or perhaps a
game of checkers."
"Yes there are a certain number of possible obvious moves, the point being to say
all yours first in an attempt to exhaust the
enemy's supply of ammunition and make him
feel uncomfortable, or to get him up in a corner and
"Make him propose," said she. "You
are progressing."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE PRESIDENT'S RECEPTION.
On Friday, March fifteenth a very pleasant
musical was given to the student body by the
President and Mrs. Remsen in Coy Hall. It
is not often that we, at Hopkins, are favored
with anything but "shop" work, and as one
of the students aptly remarked, it is certainly
most delightful to hear really good music
again. Yet besides the pleasure of an entertainment of this kind there is a real and permanent value in that it gives an opportunity
for social development, and for the improvement and refinement of those qualities which,
though not found on any curriculum are
always expected in a college man. In behalf
of the student body the NEWS-LETTER takes
this opportunity to thank President and Mrs.
Remsen, and would also say that it hopes the
President's reception will become a fixed custom at Hopkins. It is probable that another
will be given soon.

wrote asking for funds to make the purchase.
Mr. Buckley and other generously responded,
sending some three thousand dollars. When
the funds were at hand, however, the price
asked was so exorbitant that Dr. Wilson,
with the consent of the donors of the money,
wisely decided to spend the money in purchases, as the opportunity presents itself.
In conjunction with Dr. Wilson, Dr. Robinson will give two new courses next year
open to undergraduates, one on Greek and
Roman antiquities, the other on Greek and
Roman private life. The first will be a three
hour course; the second has not yet been
definitely arranged. At any rate, they will
offer great help to the classical student in
helping him to get into the spirit of the Greek
and Roman writers.

LEVERING HALL.

HOPKINS NIGHT.

INTERCOLLEGIATE CONFERENCE.

The next Hopkins Night will be held on
Tuesday, April 23, at the Academy of Music.
The attraction is the musical comedy "Noah's
Ark." The show is entirely new, and will
have its premiere the night before, with Harry
Bulger, of "Woodland" fame, and Maida
Snyder, at the head of the caste. The comedy
is said to be one of the best of recent years,
and certainly ought to be attractive with
Bulger at its head. This will be an excellent
opportunity for some of the former "supes"
to get a job, and doubtless they would be
well repaid by their experiences behind the
scenes of such a show.
The committee is waking every effort to
have this night a record-breaker, and they
hope that that night will see present a goodly
number of Hopkins men as well as outsiders.
The show is well worth the money, and there
is no reason why we won't have a good crowd,
provided every man conies up at the proper
time.

The conference, held on March 9, was attended by about sixty delegates from twelve
colleges in Maryland and the District of
Columbia. The speakers were Messrs. Fennell P. Turner and J. A. Lovell Murray, Dr.
Griggs of Peking, China, now studying at the
Hopkins Medical School, and Mrs. Hoskins
of Beirut, Syria. Out-of-town students were
entertained by Hopkins men. Supper was
served in Levering Hall.

HOPKINS AT JAMESTOWN.
A space twenty-six by fifteen feet in a
desirable part of the Educational Building has
been set aside for our exhibit at Jamestown.
Our display is limited practically to four lines
representing mainly the scientific activities of
the University.
First. There will be a full set of handsomely-bound scientific journals, theses and
other University publications.
Second. The Biological Department will
be represented by specimens illustrating the
oyster in all its phases of development.
Plenty of information will be on hand in the
various publications previously made on the
subject of the oyster. The cray-fish and

9

THE NEWS-LETTER.

other objects will illustrate the work in
Marine Zoology.
Third. From the Physical Department will
be sent a photographic map of the solar
spectrum, diffraction gratings, and an apparatus showing modifications of the Cavendish experiment.
Fourth. Maps, charts and models will
show work now in progress in Geological
Meteorology.
Publications from the Economic Department
on subjects under recent investigation, specimens of papyrus received from Egypt, and a
tablet, prepared by Dr. Haupt, giving the
Chaldean account of the deluge,will practically
omplete the exhibition.

THE FRESHMAN LACROSSE TEAM.
In spite of all that has been said of the
Freshman lack of spirit, they have gotten
their candidates together and held two regular lineups. Of course, these lineups have
just been to teach them the elementary principles of the game, for only three of the
Freshmen have ever had a stick in their hand
before they came to Hopkins.
The candidates are working hard and show
good spirit, but as the team is mostly new in
every respect, the men will not be assigned to
their positions for some time. The days for
the class games have not yet been decided on.

HOPKINS, 8; MARYLAND AGRICULTURAL
COLLEGE, 7.
On March 30, the baseball team opened its
season by defeating the Maryland Agricultural
College in a very pretty game which took
eleven innings to decide. M. A. C. scored
first, making two runs in the first inning,
but in the fourth Hopkins was two runs
ahead. By the sixth the score was even, and
from that point until the eleventh neither side
could score. In this inning the visitors made
two runs, and it looked as though they might
will out after all. Our chances looked particularly bad when our first two men struck out,
but the third got to first somehow, and then
turned. With a two-bagger from Maynard
we tied the score, and a moment later on a
single from Watkins won tne game.

PENNSYLVANIA, 16; HOPKINS, 1.
On April 1st the team was badly beaten by
the fast nine of the University of Pennsylvania. As a baseball game the exhibition was
exceedingly poor, for it was merely a test of
which set of men could endure the most cold,

TRACK.
The out-door season is on hand for sports
and, already, the members of the Track team
have enjoyed the rush of the wind in their
faces, and have had the pleasure of taking
enjoyable trips on crowded trolley-cars,
through such pleasant quiet scenes as one
find on Pratt street.
The United Railway Company and the
weather man seem bound to keep the track
team from training; the former by not furnishing a more convenient means of transportation
to Patterson Park, and the latter by furnishing a too-abundant supply of snow in the
second week in April.
In spite of these difficulties, however, the
season has fairly commenced, and either because it is the custom or because one naturally feels optimistic after the Easter examinations are over, we find it incumbent to predict
a very successful season.
The first event to come off is the Pennsylvania Relay Races, and needless to say every
one is confident of success, even our opponents. The men are rounding into fine form
(all track men should have good forms, although, alas, many have not) and best of all,
they are not new. Padgett, Stewart, Hunter
and Perce have all had experience on the
team before, and Treading, Graves and the
other candidates for positions all know what
it is to have a track shoe on. The struggle
for places on the team should be hard fought
this year, and that always brings out the best
team possible in the University.
The squad now is quite large. Nearly
every one, whoever pretended to run, is quite
enthusiastic at present, and you can see quite
a few men daily running up and down the

THE NEWS-LETTER.

cage in the abbreviated track suit. The track
picture will be taken soon.
The outlook for the Virginia dual meet
is not so favorable as it was last year. The
loss of Hill, Knight and several other good
men, through graduation or otherwise, makes
it necessary to develop new men to take their
places and at present these new men are not
over-plentiful.
The teams greatest weakness is in the field
events. There is a lack of weight-men and
jumpers, and it is the duty of every man who
ever did anything in these lines to come out
and help beat Virginia.
If Hopkins is to beat Virginia and the
Naval Academy this year, it means hard
work, not hard work by a few, but by a concentrated effort by the whole undergraduate
body. As a united body, we may hope to accomplish much, so get together.

LACROSSE.
As probably every one knows, the lacrosse
season opened on Saturday, April sixth, with
the game between the Alumni and the 'Varsity. The former team was composed of
former players and scrubs from this year's
and, of course, had little or no team work.
Nevertheless, they put up an excellent game
and were the first to score. That first goal
was well earned by the Alumni, and the
'Varsity defense was certainly "up in the air"
when it was made. Coming as it did, after
about three minutes of play, it caused some
of the Alumni to chortle in high glee, and
several of the wiseacres on the sidelines began
to shake their heads and make dire prophecies
as to what would be the outcome of the game,
and even the season. Their doubts and fears
were quickly dispelled later, however, for
when the 'Varsity struck their pace, they did
not let up until the last whistle blew, when
there were 11 goals to the credit of the 1907
team.
The 'Varsity, in spite of their good showing, need not get puffed up. Nearly half of
the opponents were scrubs, some of whom were
playing for the first time in a regular game,
Therefore, because they shot 11 goals is no
sign that they will have an easy time with
Mt. Washington or Swarthmore, later on.

BALTIMORE, MD.

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Alumni had no team-work, and were, of
course, in no condition, but the two teams
just mentioned will be in first-class condition
and have excellent team-work by the time
the games come off.
The Alumni defense was stronger than
their attack, and as a result, the 'Varsity attack had to work harder than the 'Varsity
defense. The latter missed the services of
Captain Tough, who thought it wiser to stay
out of the game, on account of a little soreness in his leg. As a result the defense did
not strike the proper gait until the second
half, when the goal was scarcely threatened.
It was pleasing to see Dr. Abercrombie and
some of the other "old men" come out and
show flashes of their old-time form. The appearance of the doctor's red and white cap
called forth remembrances of past days when
the owner of that cap played center, and the
bobbing tassel would be seen in all parts of
the field.
Dill, Fred. Blanck and "Bill" Schmeisser have been practicing with Mt. Washington, and, of course, are more familiar to the
present generation than Abercrombie, Iglehart and Hazlehurst.
The day was cold, and hence, the attendance was not so good as it might have been.
Let us hope the rooters will come out strong
at the next games. They are all in Baltimore,
except the Swarthmore game, and they will
all be worth seeing. They ought to be just
as interesting as the Swarthmore game of last
year, for the teams are very evenly matched.
Here is a chance for some good hard rooting,
Wake up!
